title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Miles is going to spend 1/6 of a day reading. He will read comic books, graphic novels, and novels. He reads 21 pages an hour when he reads novels, 30 pages an hour when he reads graphic novels, and 45 pages an hour when he reads comic books. If he reads each for 1/3 of his time, how many pages does he read?

He will read for 24 / 6 = <<24/6=4>>4 hours.
He will read each for 4 / 3 = <<4/3=1.3333333333333333>>1.3333333333333333 hours.
First find the number of pages he reads from novels: 21 pages/hour * 1.3333333333333333 hours = <<21*1.3333333333333333=28>>28 pages
Then find the number of pages he reads from graphic novels: 30 pages/hour * 1.3333333333333333 hours = <<30*1.3333333333333333=40>>40 pages
Then find the number of pages he reads from comic books: 45 pages/hour * 1.3333333333333333 hours = <<45*1.3333333333333333=60>>60 pages
Then add all three amounts of pages he reads to find the total number: 28 pages + 40 pages + 60 pages = <<28+40+60=128>>128 pages. Answer: \boxed{128}.


Question: Miles is going to spend 1/6 of a day reading. He will read comic books, graphic novels, and novels. He reads 21 pages an hour when he reads novels, 30 pages an hour when he reads graphic novels, and 45 pages an hour when he reads comic books. If he reads each for 1/3 of his time, how many pages does he read?

He spends 4 hours reading because 1 / (1/6) = <<1/(1/6)=6>>6
He reads each for 1.33 hours because 4 / 3 = <<4/3=1.33>>1.33
He reads 28 pages a book because 1.33 x 21 = <<1.33*21=27.93>>27.93
He reads 40 pages of the graphic novels because 1.33 x 30 = <<1.33*30=39.9>>39.9
He reads 60 pages of the comics because 1.33 x 45 = <<1.33*45=59.85>>59.85
He reads 125 pages in total because 27.93 + 39.9 + 59.85 = <<27.93+39.9+59.85=127.68>>127.68. Answer: \boxed{128}.


Question: Miles is going to spend 1/6 of a day reading. He will read comic books, graphic novels, and novels. He reads 21 pages an hour when he reads novels, 30 pages an hour when he reads graphic novels, and 45 pages an hour when he reads comic books. If he reads each for 1/3 of his time, how many pages does he read?

Miles will spend 24 / 6 = <<24/6=4>>4 hours of his day reading.
Each type of book will get 4 / 3 = <<4/3=1.3333333333333333>>1.3333 hours.
To read novels Miles reads 1.333 * 21 = <<1.333*21=28>>28 pages.
To read graphic novels Miles reads 1.333 * 30 = <<1.333*30=40>>40 pages.
To read comic books Miles reads 1.333 * 45 = <<1.333*45=60>>60 pages.
Total Miles will read 28 + 40 + 60 = <<28+40+60=128>>128 pages. Answer: \boxed{128}.


Question: Rob planned on spending three hours reading in preparation for his literature exam. If he ends up spending only three-quarters of this time reading, and he reads a page every fifteen minutes, how many pages did he read in this time?

Rob initially planned to read for three hours, which is equal to 3 * 60 = <<3*60=180>>180 minutes.
However, he ended up reading only 3/4 * 180 = <<3/4*180=135>>135 minutes.
If he reads a page every 15 minutes, Rob would be able to read a total of 135 / 15 = <<135/15=9>>9 pages. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Rob planned on spending three hours reading in preparation for his literature exam. If he ends up spending only three-quarters of this time reading, and he reads a page every fifteen minutes, how many pages did he read in this time?

Three-quarters of the three hours he planned to read is 3*(3/4)=<<3*(3/4)=2.25>>2.25 hours
1 hour is made up of 60 minutes, meaning in 2.25 hours, he read=2.25*60=<<2.25*60=135>>135 minutes
Since he reads a page every 15 minutes, he read 135/15=<<135/15=9>>9 pages in the 2.25 hours. Answer: \boxed{9}.


Question: Miles is going to spend 1/6 of a day reading. He will read comic books, graphic novels, and novels. He reads 21 pages an hour when he reads novels, 30 pages an hour when he reads graphic novels, and 45 pages an hour when he reads comic books. If he reads each for 1/3 of his time, how many pages does he read?
text:
Miles will spend 1/6 of a day, which is 24/6 = 4 hours, reading.
He will spend 1/3 of his time on each type of book, so he will spend 4/3 = 1.3333333333333333 hours on each book.
To find the number of pages he reads from novels, multiply the number of hours he spends on novels (1.3333333333333333) by the number of pages he reads per hour (21): 1.3333333333333333 * 21 = 28 pages.
Similarly, for graphic novels: 1.3333333333333333 * 30 = 40 pages.
And for comic books: 1.3333333333333333 * 45 = 60 pages.
Finally, add the number of pages he reads from each type of book to find the total number of pages: 28 + 40 + 60 = 128 pages.
Therefore, Miles will read 128 pages. Answer: \boxed{128}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A man decides to try and do everything off his bucket list while he is still young and fit enough to finish it all.  One of his goals was to climb the seven summits.  He realizes first he has to get in shape to do it and it takes him 2 years of working out to get healthy enough to take up mountain climbing.  He then spends twice that long learning how to be a technically proficient mountain climber.  After that he starts with the simplest mountain on the list and climbs them all.  He spends 5 months climbing each mountain.  After that he takes 13 months learning to dive and dives through all the caves he wants in 2 years.  How much time did it take to get through all these goals?

First, the man spent 2 years working out and getting in shape.
Then, he spent twice that long, which is 2 * 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 years learning how to be a technically proficient mountain climber.
After that, he spent 5 months climbing each of the seven mountains, so in total 5 * 7 = <<5*7=35>>35 months.
Converting the months to years, we get 35 / 12 = <<35/12=2.9166666666666665>>2.92 years.
Next, he spent 13 months learning to dive, which is 13 / 12 = <<13/12=1.0833333333333333>>1.08 years.
Finally, he spent 2 years diving through all the caves he wanted.
In total, the man spent 2 + 4 + 2.92 + 1.08 + 2 = <<2+4+2.92+1.08+2=12>>12 years to complete all these goals. Answer: \boxed{12}.


Question: Roger uses his lunch break to walk the stairs in his office building.  He can walk 2,000 steps in 30 minutes.  If his daily goal is 10,000 steps, how many minutes will it take him to reach his goal?

He walks 2000 steps in 30 minutes and his goal is 10,000 steps. This means he walks 10000/2000 = <<10000/2000=5>>5 times his goal
It takes him 30 minutes to reach 2000 steps and he does this 5 times so it will take him 30*5 = <<30*5=150>>150 minutes. Answer: \boxed{150}.


Question: James decides to try and collect rare artifacts in the field.  He spends 6 months researching before going on a 2-year-long expedition for his first find.  The second artifact takes 3 times as long for the research and discovery.  How long did it take him to find both?

The research took 6/12=<<6/12=.5>>.5 years
So the first artifact took 2+.5=<<2.5=2.5>>2.5 years
That means the second artifact took 2.5*3=<<2.5*3=7.5>>7.5 years
So in total, it took 2.5+7.5=<<2.5+7.5=10>>10 years. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: Micah, Dean, and Jake are all training for a marathon organized by a local NGO to support children in their town who have cancer. Micah runs 2/3 times as fast as Dean. It takes Jake 1/3 times more time to finish the marathon than it takes Mica. If Dean takes 9 hours, what's the total time the three take to complete the marathon?

Micah runs 2/3 times as fast as Dean, which means Micah takes 2/3 * 9 = <<2/3*9=6>>6 hours to finish the marathon.
Jake takes 1/3 times more time to finish the marathon than it takes Micah, which means Jake takes 1/3 * 6 = <<1/3*6=2>>2 more hours to finish the marathon.
The total time Jake takes to finish the marathon is 6 + 2 = <<6+2=8>>8 hours.
The total time the three take to finish the marathon is 8 + 6 + 9 = <<8+6+9=23>>23 hours. Answer: \boxed{23}.


Question: John decides to go back to school to get his PhD.  He first takes 1 year of courses to get acclimated back to school life before starting his PhD.  After that, he spends 2 years learning the basics of his field.  He then starts research, and he spends 75% more time on research than he did learning the basics.  He then spends half as long on writing his dissertation as his acclimation period.  How long did it take him to do everything?

He spends 2*.75=<<2*.75=1.5>>1.5 years more on research than he did learning the basics.
So he spent 2+1.5=<<2+1.5=3.5>>3.5 years on research.
He spent 1/2=<<1/2=0.5>>0.5 years writing his dissertation.
So in total, he spent 2+3.5+0.5+1=<<2+3.5+0.5+1=7>>7 years on everything. Answer: \boxed{7}.


Question: A man decides to try and do everything off his bucket list while he is still young and fit enough to finish it all.  One of his goals was to climb the seven summits.  He realizes first he has to get in shape to do it and it takes him 2 years of working out to get healthy enough to take up mountain climbing.  He then spends twice that long learning how to be a technically proficient mountain climber.  After that he starts with the simplest mountain on the list and climbs them all.  He spends 5 months climbing each mountain.  After that he takes 13 months learning to dive and dives through all the caves he wants in 2 years.  How much time did it take to get through all these goals?
text:
First, the man spent 2 years working out and getting in shape.
Then, he spent twice that long, which is 2 * 2 = 4 years learning how to be a technically proficient mountain climber.
After that, he spent 5 months climbing each of the seven mountains, so in total 5 * 7 = 35 months.
Converting the months to years, we get 35 / 12 = 2.92 years.
Next, he spent 13 months learning to dive, which is 13 / 12 = 1.08 years.
Finally, he spent 2 years diving through all the caves he wanted.
In total, the man spent 2 + 4 + 2.92 + 1.08 + 2 = 12 years to complete all these goals. Answer: \boxed{12}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A fixer uses 30% of the nails in a container to repair the kitchen. He also used 70% of the remaining nails in the container to repair the fence. If there were 400 nails in the container, how many nails are remaining?

The fixer used 30/100*400 = <<30/100*400=120>>120 nails to repair the kitchen.
The number of nails in the container after the kitchen repair is 400-120 = <<400-120=280>>280
When he used 70/100*280 = <<70/100*280=196>>196 nails to repair the fence.
The number of remaining nails is 280-196 = <<280-196=84>>84. Answer: \boxed{84}.


Question: A fixer uses 30% of the nails in a container to repair the kitchen. He also used 70% of the remaining nails in the container to repair the fence. If there were 400 nails in the container, how many nails are remaining?

The fixer used 400 x 30/100 = <<400*30/100=120>>120 nails to repair the kitchen.
So, 400 - 120 = <<400-120=280>>280 nails were left in the container.
Then, he used another 280 x 70/100 = <<280*70/100=196>>196 nails to repair the fence.
That means, 280 - 196 = <<280-196=84>>84 nails are remaining. Answer: \boxed{84}.


Question: A fixer uses 30% of the nails in a container to repair the kitchen. He also used 70% of the remaining nails in the container to repair the fence. If there were 400 nails in the container, how many nails are remaining?

The fixer used 30/100*400 = <<30/100*400=120>>120 nails to repair the kitchen.
The total number of nails remaining in the container is 400-120 = <<400-120=280>>280.
The fixer also used 70/100*280 = <<70/100*280=196>>196 nails to repair the fence.
The total number of nails remaining in the container is 280-196 = <<280-196=84>>84. Answer: \boxed{84}.


Question: A fixer uses 30% of the nails in a container to repair the kitchen. He also used 70% of the remaining nails in the container to repair the fence. If there were 400 nails in the container, how many nails are remaining?

The fixer used 400 x 30/100 = <<400*30/100=120>>120 nails to repair the kitchen.
So, there were 400 - 120 = <<400-120=280>>280 nails left in the container.
Then, 280 x 70/100 = <<280*70/100=196>>196 nails were used to repair the fence.
Therefore, there are 280 - 196 = <<280-196=84>>84 nails remaining. Answer: \boxed{84}.


Question: Jill is painting her 20 toenails and fingernails. She paints 6 of her nails purple, 8 of them blue, and the rest striped. What is the difference in percentage points between the percentage of nails painted blue and the percentage painted striped?

There are a total of 20 nails. If we subtract the number of purple nails and blue nails, we find that 20-6-8=<<20-6-8=6>>6 nails are striped.
The percentage of nails that are blue is 8/20=0.4*100%=<<8/20=40>>40%.
The percentage of nails that are striped is 6/20=0.3*100%=<<6/20=30>>30%.
The difference in percentage points between the percentage of nails painted blue and striped is 40-30=<<40-30=10>>10%. Answer: \boxed{10}.


Question: A fixer uses 30% of the nails in a container to repair the kitchen. He also used 70% of the remaining nails in the container to repair the fence. If there were 400 nails in the container, how many nails are remaining?
text:
The fixer used 30% of 400 nails, which is 0.3*400 = 120 nails, to repair the kitchen.
So, there were 400 - 120 = 280 nails left in the container.
Then, the fixer used 70% of the remaining 280 nails, which is 0.7*280 = 196 nails, to repair the fence.
Therefore, there are 280 - 196 = 84 nails remaining. Answer: \boxed{84}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Jen bought a bag of cookies and ate three-quarters of the bag that day. The next day, she ate half of the remaining cookies. She has 8 cookies left on the third day. How many cookies were in the bag to start?

Let X be the starting number of cookies.
On the first day, Jen ate 3/4*X cookies.
On the second day, she had (1 - 3/4) * X = 1/4*X cookies remaining.
On the third day, she ate 1/2 * 1/4*X = 1/8*X cookies.
Jen has X-3/4*X - 1/4*X - 1/8*X = 8 cookies left.
Combining like terms, we get 1/8*X = 8.
X = 64 cookies. Answer: \boxed{64}.


Question: Jen bought a bag of cookies and ate three-quarters of the bag that day. The next day, she ate half of the remaining cookies. She has 8 cookies left on the third day. How many cookies were in the bag to start?

Let C be the number of cookies in the bag.
Jen ate 3/4*C cookies on the first day.
She ate 1/2*(C-3/4*C) = 1/2*(1/4*C) = 1/8*C cookies on the second day.
She has C - 3/4*C - 1/8*C = 8 cookies left on the third day.
Combining like terms, we get 1/8*C = 8
Dividing both sides by 1/8, we get C = 8 / (1/8)= 8 * 8 = <<8/(1/8)=64>>64. Answer: \boxed{64}.


Question: Jen bought a bag of cookies and ate three-quarters of the bag that day. The next day, she ate half of the remaining cookies. She has 8 cookies left on the third day. How many cookies were in the bag to start?

Let x be the number of cookies in the bag initially.
Jen ate 3/4 * x cookies on the first day, so on the second day, there were x - 3/4 * x = 1/4 * x cookies left.
Jen ate 1/2 * (1/4 * x) = 1/8 * x cookies on the second day.
On the third day, there were 1/4 * x - 1/8 * x = 8 cookies left.
Combining the like terms, we get 2/8 * x - 1/8 * x = 8.
Combining the x terms, we get 1/8 * x = 8.
Dividing both sides by 1/8, we get x = 8 / (1/8) = 8 * 8 = <<8/(1/8)=64>>64 cookies. Answer: \boxed{64}.


Question: Jen bought a bag of cookies and ate three-quarters of the bag that day. The next day, she ate half of the remaining cookies. She has 8 cookies left on the third day. How many cookies were in the bag to start?

Let x be the number of cookies in the bag to start
On the first day, she ate 3/4 * x cookies and left x / 4 cookies
On the second day, she ate 1/2 * (x / 4) = x / 8 cookies
On the third day, she has (x / 4) - (x / 8) = 8 cookies
Multiplying through the parentheses shows that 8 = (x / 4) - (x / 8)
Multiplying both sides of the equation by 8*8 results in 8 * 64 = 2 * x - x
64 = x. Answer: \boxed{64}.


Question: Uncle Jude baked 256 cookies. He gave 15 cookies to Tim, 23 cookies to Mike, kept some in the fridge and gave the rest to Anna. How many cookies did he put in the fridge if he gave twice as many cookies as he gave Tim to Anna?

Since he gave Tim 15 cookies, Anna received 2 * 15 cookies = <<2*15=30>>30 cookies.
In total, Uncle Jude gave 15 cookies + 23 cookies + 30 cookies = <<15+23+30=68>>68 cookies.
So he put 256 cookies - 68 cookies = <<256-68=188>>188 cookies in the fridge. Answer: \boxed{188}.


Question: Jen bought a bag of cookies and ate three-quarters of the bag that day. The next day, she ate half of the remaining cookies. She has 8 cookies left on the third day. How many cookies were in the bag to start?
text:
Let's assume there were x cookies in the bag to start.
On the first day, Jen ate 3/4 * x cookies.
On the second day, she had (1 - 3/4) * x = 1/4 * x cookies remaining.
On the third day, she ate 1/2 * (1/4 * x) = 1/8 * x cookies.
Jen has x - 3/4 * x - 1/4 * x - 1/8 * x = 8 cookies left.
Combining like terms, we get 1/8 * x = 8.
Dividing both sides by 1/8, we get x = 8 / (1/8) = 8 * 8 = 64.
Therefore, there were 64 cookies in the bag to start. Answer: \boxed{64}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A library has a number of books. 35% of them are intended for children and 104 of them are for adults. How many books are in the library?

Let X be the number of books in the library.
The number of children's books is X * 35% = 0.35X.
The number of books for adults is X - 0.35X = 0.65X = 104
Thus X = 104 / 0.65 = <<104/0.65=160>>160 books. Answer: \boxed{160}.


Question: A library has a number of books. 35% of them are intended for children and 104 of them are for adults. How many books are in the library?

Let x be the number of books in the library.
The number of children's book is x * 35% = x * 0.35.
The total number of books for adults and children is x * 0.35 + 104 = x.
Thus, x * 0.35 + 104 = x.
Thus, 0.35x + 104 = x.
Thus, 104 = x - 0.35x.
Thus, 0.65x = 104.
Thus, x = 104 / 0.65 = 160 books in the library. Answer: \boxed{160}.


Question: A library has a number of books. 35% of them are intended for children and 104 of them are for adults. How many books are in the library?

Let X be the number of books in the library.
There are X * 35/100 = <<X*35/100=0.35*X>>0.35*X children's books.
Since there are 104 adult books, then X - 0.35*X = 104.
Combining like terms, we get 0.65*X = 104.
Dividing both sides by 0.65, we get X = 160. Answer: \boxed{160}.


Question: A library has a number of books. 35% of them are intended for children and 104 of them are for adults. How many books are in the library?

Let the total number of books in the library be x.
35% of the books are intended for children, which is 35/100 * x = 0.35x.
The number of books intended for adults is 104.
Thus, the number of books intended for children is x - 104.
0.35x = x - 104
0.35x - x = -104
0.65x = 104
x = 104 / 0.65 = <<104/0.65=160>>160
Therefore, there are 160 books in the library. Answer: \boxed{160}.


Question: A library has a collection of 100 historical novels arranged on a shelf. 5 people borrow 2 books each from the shelf on a particular day,  and 20 more books are borrowed from the shelf on the second day. How many books are remaining on the shelf after the second day?

On the first day, each of the 5 people borrowed 2 books each, a total of 2*5=<<2*5=10>>10 books.
After day one, the number of books remaining on the shelf is 100-10 = <<100-10=90>>90 books.
On the second day, 20 more books were borrowed resulting in 90- 20= <<90-20=70>>70 books were remaining. Answer: \boxed{70}.


Question: A library has a number of books. 35% of them are intended for children and 104 of them are for adults. How many books are in the library?
text:
Let x be the number of books in the library.
The number of children's books is 35% of x, which is 0.35x.
The number of books for adults is 104.
So, the total number of books is the sum of the children's books and the books for adults:
x = 0.35x + 104
Subtracting 0.35x from both sides gives:
0.65x = 104
Dividing both sides by 0.65 gives:
x = 104 / 0.65 = 160
Therefore, there are 160 books in the library. Answer: \boxed{160}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Janine read 5 books last month. This month, she read twice as many books. If each book has 10 pages, how many pages did Janine read in two months?

Last month, Janine read 5 books * 10 pages/book = <<5*10=50>>50 pages.
This month she read 5 books * 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 books.
In total, she read 10 books * 10 pages/book = <<10*10=100>>100 pages.
So in two months, Janine read 50 pages + 100 pages = <<50+100=150>>150 pages. Answer: \boxed{150}.


Question: Janine read 5 books last month. This month, she read twice as many books. If each book has 10 pages, how many pages did Janine read in two months?

This month, Janine read 5 x 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 books.
Janine read a total of 5 + 10 = <<5+10=15>>15 books in two months.
She read a total of 15 x 10 = <<15*10=150>>150 pages in two months. Answer: \boxed{150}.


Question: Janine read 5 books last month. This month, she read twice as many books. If each book has 10 pages, how many pages did Janine read in two months?

Janine read 5 x 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 books this month.
She read a total of 5 + 10 = <<5+10=15>>15 books in two months.
So, Janine read a total of 15 x 10 = <<15*10=150>>150 pages in two months. Answer: \boxed{150}.


Question: Janine read 5 books last month. This month, she read twice as many books. If each book has 10 pages, how many pages did Janine read in two months?

Last month Janine read 5*10=<<5*10=50>>50 pages.
This month, she read 5*2=<<5*2=10>>10 books.
That is a total of 10*10=<<10*10=100>>100 pages.
In total, Janine read 50+100=<<50+100=150>>150 pages in two months. Answer: \boxed{150}.


Question: Janine read 5 books last month. This month, she read twice as many books. If each book has 10 pages, how many pages did Janine read in two months?

Janine read 5 x 2 = <<5*2=10>>10 books this month.
Thus, she read a total of 5 + 10 = <<5+10=15>>15 books in two months.
Therefore, she read 15 x 10 = <<15*10=150>>150 pages. Answer: \boxed{150}.


Question: Janine read 5 books last month. This month, she read twice as many books. If each book has 10 pages, how many pages did Janine read in two months?
text:
Last month, Janine read 5 books * 10 pages/book = 50 pages.
This month she read 5 books * 2 = 10 books.
In total, she read 10 books * 10 pages/book = 100 pages.
So in two months, Janine read 50 pages + 100 pages = 150 pages. Answer: \boxed{150}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: A movie ticket costs $5. The cost of the popcorn is 80% of the cost of the ticket and a can of soda costs 50% of the cost of the popcorn. A family bought 4 tickets, 2 sets of popcorn, and 4 cans of soda. How much did they spend?

The cost of the popcorn is $5 x 80/100 = $4.
The cost of a can of soda is $4 x 50/100 = $2.
So, a family spent $5 x 4 = $<<5*4=20>>20 for the movie tickets.
They spend $4 x 2 = $<<4*2=8>>8 for the popcorn.
And they spend $2 x 4 = $<<2*4=8>>8 for the sodas.
Therefore, the family spent $20 + $8 + $8 = $<<20+8+8=36>>36 in all. Answer: \boxed{36}.


Question: A movie ticket costs $5. The cost of the popcorn is 80% of the cost of the ticket and a can of soda costs 50% of the cost of the popcorn. A family bought 4 tickets, 2 sets of popcorn, and 4 cans of soda. How much did they spend?

The cost of popcorn is $5 x 80/100 = $<<5*80/100=4>>4.
The cost of soda is $4 x 50/100 = $<<4*50/100=2>>2.
They spent $5 x 4 = $<<5*4=20>>20 for the tickets.
They spent $4 x 2 = $<<4*2=8>>8 for the popcorn.
They spent $2 x 4 = $<<2*4=8>>8 for the soda.
Therefore, they spent a total of $20 + $8 + $8 = $<<20+8+8=36>>36. Answer: \boxed{36}.


Question: A movie theater company is advertising a deal of a movie ticket, a bucket of popcorn, a drink, and a box of candy for $20. Normally, a movie ticket costs $8, a bucket of popcorn costs three dollars less, a drink costs a dollar more than popcorn, and a candy costs half as much as a drink. How many dollars does the deal save a customer who buys a ticket, popcorn, drink, and candy normally?

First find the cost of the popcorn: $8 - $3 = $<<8-3=5>>5
Then find the cost of the drink: $5 + $1 = $<<5+1=6>>6
Then find the cost of the candy: $6 / 2 = $<<6/2=3>>3
Then add the cost of each item to find the total: $8 + $5 + $6 + $3 = $<<8+5+6+3=22>>22
Then subtract the cost of the deal from the normal cost to find the savings: $22 - $20 = $<<22-20=2>>2. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A movie theater company is advertising a deal of a movie ticket, a bucket of popcorn, a drink, and a box of candy for $20. Normally, a movie ticket costs $8, a bucket of popcorn costs three dollars less, a drink costs a dollar more than popcorn, and a candy costs half as much as a drink. How many dollars does the deal save a customer who buys a ticket, popcorn, drink, and candy normally?

The cost of a bucket of popcorn is $8 - $3 = $<<8-3=5>>5.
The cost of a drink is $5 + $1 = $<<5+1=6>>6.
The cost of a candy is $6/2 = $<<6/2=3>>3.
Therefore, the total cost is $8 + $5 + $6 + $3 = $<<8+5+6+3=22>>22.
Therefore, the deal saves the customer $22 - $20 = $<<22-20=2>>2. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A movie theater company is advertising a deal of a movie ticket, a bucket of popcorn, a drink, and a box of candy for $20. Normally, a movie ticket costs $8, a bucket of popcorn costs three dollars less, a drink costs a dollar more than popcorn, and a candy costs half as much as a drink. How many dollars does the deal save a customer who buys a ticket, popcorn, drink, and candy normally?

A bucket of popcorn normally costs $8 - $3 = $<<8-3=5>>5.
A drink normally costs $5 + $1 = $<<5+1=6>>6.
A box of candy normally costs $6 / 2 = $<<6/2=3>>3.
So normally a customer pays $8 + $5 + $6 + $3 = $<<8+5+6+3=22>>22.
Therefore, the deal saves a customer $22 - $20 = $<<22-20=2>>2. Answer: \boxed{2}.


Question: A movie ticket costs $5. The cost of the popcorn is 80% of the cost of the ticket and a can of soda costs 50% of the cost of the popcorn. A family bought 4 tickets, 2 sets of popcorn, and 4 cans of soda. How much did they spend?
text:
The cost of the popcorn is $5 x 80/100 = $<<5*80/100=4>>4.
The cost of a can of soda is $4 x 50/100 = $<<4*50/100=2>>2.
So, a family spent $5 x 4 = $<<5*4=20>>20 for the movie tickets.
They spend $4 x 2 = $<<4*2=8>>8 for the popcorn.
And they spend $2 x 4 = $<<2*4=8>>8 for the sodas.
Therefore, the family spent $20 + $8 + $8 = $<<20+8+8=36>>36 in all. Answer: \boxed{36}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight. Together they weigh 98 kilograms. How many kilograms does Antoinette weigh?

Let's call Rupert's weight "x".
Antoinette's weight is twice Rupert's weight minus 7 kilograms, or 2x - 7.
Together they weigh x + (2x - 7) = 98 kilograms.
Combining like terms, we get 3x - 7 = 98.
Adding 7 to both sides, we get 3x = 105.
Dividing both sides by 3, we get x = 35.
Antoinette's weight is 2 * 35 - 7 = 70 - 7 = <<2*35-7=63>>63 kilograms. Answer: \boxed{63}.


Question: Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight. Together they weigh 98 kilograms. How many kilograms does Antoinette weigh?

Let R be Rupert's weight.
Antoinette weighs 2R - 7 kilograms.
R + 2R - 7 = 98
3R = 105
R = <<35=35>>35
Antoinette weighs 2 * 35 - 7 = <<2*35-7=63>>63 kilograms. Answer: \boxed{63}.


Question: Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight. Together they weigh 98 kilograms. How many kilograms does Antoinette weigh?

Let R be the weight of Rupert.
Antoinette = 2R - 7.
R + 2R - 7 = 98
3R = 105
R = <<35=35>>35 kilograms
Antoinette = 2 * 35 - 7 = <<2*35-7=63>>63 kilograms
Antoinette weighs 63 kilograms. Answer: \boxed{63}.


Question: Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight. Together they weigh 98 kilograms. How many kilograms does Antoinette weigh?

Let's say Rupert's weight is R kilograms.
If Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight, she weighs 2*R - 7 kilograms.
The total weight of the two is R + 2*R - 7 = 98 kilograms.
Combining like terms, we get 3*R - 7 = 98.
Adding 7 to both sides, we get 3*R = 105.
Dividing both sides by 3, we get R = 35 kilograms.
Since Antoinette weighs 2*R - 7 = 2*35 - 7 = 70 - 7 = <<2*35-7=63>>63 kilograms. Answer: \boxed{63}.


Question: Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight. Together they weigh 98 kilograms. How many kilograms does Antoinette weigh?

Let's assume Rupert's weight is x kilograms.
Twice Rupert's weight is 2*x = 2x.
Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight, which is 2x -7.
The total weight of both Antoinette and Rupert is 98 kilograms, which is equal to x + (2x - 7).
Combining like terms, the equation becomes 3x - 7 = 98.
Adding 7 to both sides of the equation, we get 3x = 105.
Dividing both sides by 3, we get x = 35.
Therefore, Antoinette weighs 2x - 7 = 2(35) - 7 = 63 kilograms. Answer: \boxed{63}.


Question: Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight. Together they weigh 98 kilograms. How many kilograms does Antoinette weigh?
text:
Let's assume that Rupert's weight is represented by the variable "x" (in kilograms).
According to the information given, Antoinette weighs 7 less kilograms than twice Rupert's weight. Therefore, Antoinette's weight can be represented as 2x - 7.
Additionally, we know that the total weight of both Antoinette and Rupert is 98 kilograms.
Combining these two pieces of information, we can set up the equation (x) + (2x - 7) = 98.
Simplifying the equation, we get 3x - 7 = 98.
Adding 7 to both sides of the equation, we have 3x = 105.
Dividing both sides of the equation by 3, we find that x = 35.
Now, we can determine Antoinette's weight by substituting the value of x back into the expression 2x - 7.
Thus, Antoinette weighs 2(35) - 7 = 70 - 7 = 63 kilograms.
Therefore, Antoinette weighs 63 kilograms. Answer: \boxed{63}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Marcus has received a commission for as many paintings as possible. Marcus plans out his drawings so that his client can receive some of the paintings as soon as possible but it is still going to take a long time. On the first day, he paints 2 paintings. He then paints every day and each day, he paints twice as many paintings as he painted the day before. If he paints for 5 days, how many paintings will he have painted in total?

On the second day, Marcus paints twice as many paintings as the first day, so he paints 2 x 2 = <<2*2=4>>4 paintings.
On the third day, he paints twice as many paintings as the second day, so he paints 4 x 2 = <<4*2=8>>8 paintings.
On the fourth day, he paints twice as many paintings as the third day, so he paints 8 x 2 = <<8*2=16>>16 paintings.
On the fifth day, he paints twice as many paintings as the fourth day, so he paints 16 x 2 = <<16*2=32>>32 paintings.
Therefore, in total Marcus will have painted 2 + 4 + 8 + 16 + 32 = <<2+4+8+16+32=62>>62 paintings. Answer: \boxed{62}.

title:
Given a math problem, generate an answer with a rationale.

Question / answer pairs have the form

Question: ${question}

${answer}
    
Examples:
    
Question: Chris is trying to sell his car for $5200 and has gotten two price offers. One buyer offered to pay the full price if Chris would pay for the car maintenance inspection, which cost a tenth of Chris’s asking price. The other buyer agreed to pay the price if Chris replaced the headlights for $80 and the tires for three times as much. What is the difference between the amounts Chris will earn from the two offers?

The first offer cost Chris $5200 / 10 = $<<5200/10=520>>520.
The second buyer is demanding he pay 3 * 80 = $<<3*80=240>>240 for the tires.
The total cost for the buyer in the second offer is 80 + 240 = $<<80+240=320>>320.
Thus, Chris earns $5200 - $520 = $<<5200-520=4680>>4680 from the first buyer.
He also earns $5200 - $320 = $<<5200-320=4880>>4880 from the second buyer.
The difference in the amount of money he earns from the two offers is $4880 - $4680 = $<<4880-4680=200>>200. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Chris is trying to sell his car for $5200 and has gotten two price offers. One buyer offered to pay the full price if Chris would pay for the car maintenance inspection, which cost a tenth of Chris’s asking price. The other buyer agreed to pay the price if Chris replaced the headlights for $80 and the tires for three times as much. What is the difference between the amounts Chris will earn from the two offers?

Chris would earn 5200 - 5200/10 = $<<5200-5200/10=4680>>4680 if he accepted the first buyer's offer.
The second buyer's offer will cost 80 + 80*3 = $<<80+80*3=320>>320 for the headlights and tires.
Thus, the second buyer's offer would earn Chris 5200 - 320 = $<<5200-320=4880>>4880.
Therefore, the difference between the amounts Chris will earn is 4880 - 4680 = $<<4880-4680=200>>200. Answer: \boxed{200}.


Question: Chris wanted to buy a new video game that costs $60 as well as an assortment of candy that costs $5.  To earn the money, he agreed to babysit his little sister for $8 per hour.  If he works 9 hours, how much money will be left over after he makes his purchases?

He will make 8*9=<<8*9=72>>72 dollars
He will spend 60+5=<<60+5=65>>65 dollars
Thus, he will have 72-65=<<72-65=7>>7 dollars left over. Answer: \boxed{7}.


Question: James decides to replace his car.  He sold his $20,000 car for 80% of its value and then was able to haggle to buy a $30,000 sticker price car for 90% of its value.  How much was he out of pocket?

He got 20000*.8=$<<20000*.8=16000>>16,000
He was able to buy it for 30000*.9=$<<30000*.9=27000>>27,000
So he had to pay 27000-16000=$<<27000-16000=11000>>11,000 out of pocket. Answer: \boxed{11,000}.


Question: Chris wanted to buy a new video game that costs $60 as well as an assortment of candy that costs $5.  To earn the money, he agreed to babysit his little sister for $8 per hour.  If he works 9 hours, how much money will be left over after he makes his purchases?

He will earn $8 an hour and works 9 hours so he will earn 8*9 = $<<8*9=72>>72
He has $72 and he needs $60 so he has 72-60 = $<<72-60=12>>12 left over
He has $12 left over and he wants to buy $5 worth of candy so he has 12-5 = $<<12-5=7>>7 left over. Answer: \boxed{7}.


Question: Chris is trying to sell his car for $5200 and has gotten two price offers. One buyer offered to pay the full price if Chris would pay for the car maintenance inspection, which cost a tenth of Chris’s asking price. The other buyer agreed to pay the price if Chris replaced the headlights for $80 and the tires for three times as much. What is the difference between the amounts Chris will earn from the two offers?
text:
The first buyer's offer requires Chris to pay $5200 / 10 = $<<5200/10=520>>520 for the car maintenance inspection.
The second buyer's offer requires Chris to pay $80 for the headlights and 3 * $80 = $<<3*80=240>>240 for the tires.
Therefore, the second buyer's offer will cost Chris a total of $80 + $240 = $<<80+240=320>>320.
From the first offer, Chris will earn $5200 - $520 = $<<5200-520=4680>>4680.
From the second offer, Chris will earn $5200 - $320 = $<<5200-320=4880>>4880.
The difference in the amounts Chris will earn is $4880 - $4680 = $<<4880-4680=200>>200. Answer: \boxed{200}.
